claim: The war doctor got more screen time than his successor in Doctor Who.

supporting.text: The War Doctor, portrayed by John Hurt, appeared in the 50th-anniversary special 'The Day of the Doctor,' which was a feature-length episode, giving him significant screen time.

attacks.text: The War Doctor, portrayed by John Hurt, appeared in the 50th-anniversary special 'The Day of the Doctor,' which was a feature-length episode, giving him significant screen time.
The War Doctor's successor, the Twelfth Doctor (Peter Capaldi), appeared in multiple full seasons, totaling far more screen time than a single special.
While the Twelfth Doctor had more cumulative screen time, the War Doctor's appearance in a high-profile, feature-length special may have left a stronger impression per minute of screen time.
The claim specifies 'screen time,' not impact or impression, making cumulative duration the only relevant metric.

supporting.text: The War Doctor's successor, the Twelfth Doctor (Peter Capaldi), had multiple full seasons, which cumulatively provided far more screen time than the War Doctor's single appearance.

attacks.text: The War Doctor's successor, the Twelfth Doctor (Peter Capaldi), had multiple full seasons, which cumulatively provided far more screen time than the War Doctor's single appearance.
The War Doctor appeared in multiple episodes and specials, including 'The Day of the Doctor,' which was a major anniversary event with extended runtime.
Even with extended runtime, 'The Day of the Doctor' and other appearances still amount to significantly less screen time than the Twelfth Doctor's three full seasons.
The War Doctor's screen time is often overlooked because his tenure was brief and not part of the main series, but his impact was substantial in the narrative.
Impact on the narrative does not equate to screen time; the Twelfth Doctor's seasons still dominate in terms of actual minutes on screen.

supporting.text: The War Doctor's role was pivotal in the Doctor Who lore, leading to his inclusion in extended media like novels and audio dramas, which could be considered as additional screen time.

attacks.text: The War Doctor's role was pivotal in the Doctor Who lore, leading to his inclusion in extended media like novels and audio dramas, which could be considered as additional screen time.
Extended media like novels and audio dramas are not officially counted as 'screen time' since they are not part of the televised episodes.
Extended media often expands on characters with limited screen time, but this does not equate to actual televised presence.
The War Doctor appeared in only one televised episode (The Day of the Doctor), while his successor had multiple seasons.

supporting.text: The Twelfth Doctor's tenure included numerous episodes and story arcs, making his screen time objectively longer when compared to the War Doctor's limited on-screen presence.

attacks.text: The Twelfth Doctor's tenure included numerous episodes and story arcs, making his screen time objectively longer when compared to the War Doctor's limited on-screen presence.
The War Doctor appeared in the 50th-anniversary special 'The Day of the Doctor,' which had a significantly longer runtime than most regular episodes, potentially balancing his screen time.
The Twelfth Doctor's tenure spanned multiple seasons with dozens of episodes, while the War Doctor only appeared in a single special and brief cameos, making his total screen time still much shorter.
The War Doctor's impact and memorability in his limited appearances may create a perception of greater screen time, even if quantitatively shorter.
